Name: Is there a distinct category of dual for verbal agreement with a dual subject?
Comment: There was agreement in the Nortern dialects of Skolt Saami quite recently but not anymore.

Name: Is non-agreement in number between the nominal subject and verbal predicate possible?
Can finite verbs agree in number with the nominal object?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in case?
Are there cases that do not show agreement in terms of case?
Comment: Adjectives don't (usually) agree with the noun case at all.

Name: Can adpositions be used to mark core verbal arguments?
Can adpositions be used to mark non-core/oblique verbal arguments?
Example: son puätt õõut da kueiʹt kõõskâst;3SG.NOM come.PRS.3SG one.GEN and two.GEN between;he is coming between one and two o'clock;Feist 2010: 308

Name: Can non-finite clauses entail a special way for a core argument (S/A) marking?
Example: suu tieʹđǩâni;3SG.GEN know.V.ABE;without him/her knowing;|suu lookkâm ǩeʹrjj;3SG.GEN read.PST.PTCP book.SG.NOM;a book that (s)he has read;

Name: Can non-finite clauses entail a special way for a core argument (P) marking?
Do characteristics of object referent (topicality, animacy, definiteness) influence object marking?
Does object marking correlate with aspectuality?
Does the marking of the object depend on the verb conjugation form?
Is there differential subject marking?
Can S and A be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e. act as syntactic pivot?
Example: son-a pâi kuuskõõzzid ǩeäčč da njorgg;3SG.NOM-EMP only aurora.PL.ACC watch.PRS.3SG and whistle.PRS.3SG;he just watches the northern lights and whistles;Feist 2010: 355

Name: Can S and P be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e. act as syntactic pivot?
Is there a grammatical device for habituality?
Is there a grammatical device for frequentative?
Example: vuõjjâd > vuõjeed;;swim : swim around;|väʹʒʒed > vaaʒʒčed;;walk : walk around;

Name: Is there a grammatical device for progressivity?
Example:
bieʹss leäi lossânji vueʹđđmen;devil.SG.NOM be.PST.3SG heavy.ADV sleep.PROG.PTCP;
the devil was sleeping deeply;Feist 2010: 266
Comment: Progressive aspect is marked with the auxiliary verb.

Name: Is it common to use a verb in the present tense for future time reference?
Example: jâđđa muäna vueʹlǧǧep meäcca;tomorrow 1DU.NOM leave.PRS.1PL forest.SG.ILL;tomorrow the two of us will go to the forest;Feist 2010: 262

Name: Is there a grammatical device for immediate future?
Is there a grammatical device for pluperfect?
Example: juʹn eeunaž leäi siʹjjid mainstam;already spider be.PST.3SG 3PL.ILL tell.PST.PTCP;Spider had already told them;Feist 2010: 264

Name: Can aspect be expressed overtly on the negative marker?
Can tense be expressed overtly on the negative marker?
Is there grammatical marking of mirativity?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of desire or wish?
Is there morphological marking for irrealis (e.g. hypothetical state of affairs)?
Example: poorčem;eat.COND.1SG;I would eat; Feist 2010: 268
Comment: Morphological marking for conditional is č.

Name: Are verbs marked in a specific mood in counterfactual conditional clauses?
Example: jiõm âʹtte mon ni kõõjjče što jos mon teâđčem leʹččem veär raajjâm ouddâl;NEG.1SG then 1SG.NOM even ask.NEG:COND COMP if 1SG.NOM know.COND.1SG be.COND.1SG food.SG.ACC prepare.PST.PTCP before;I wouldn't even ask, if I knew, if I had prepared food before;Feist 2010: 348

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic necessity?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of epistemic possibility?
Example: leʹžžem;be.POT.1SG;I may be.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic possibility?
Is there morphological marking on the verb used to express indirect commands/wishes etc. directed to the 3Sg?
Example: Peâtt mainstââǥǥas tuʹnne, što mäʹhtt tõʹst ǩiâvi;Pekka tell.IMP.3SG 2SG.ILL COMP how DIST.SG.LOC happen.PST.3SG;let Pekka tell you how things went there;Feist 2010: 330

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb used to express indirect commands/wishes etc. directed to the 1Sg?
Is it common to use the imperative/jussive in complement clauses introduced by predicates expressing wish/desire/will?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of apprehension?
Is there reflexive conjugation?
Are there syntactically ditransitive verbs?
Can non-singular 2nd and 3rd person have the same person/number marking or morphosyntactic treatment?
Can an impersonal (or passive) form be used instead of a finite plural form with an overt subject expression?
Can third person plural verb forms be used for impersonal reference?
Example: Pueʹrmõs puõccid kuõʹđđe ja hueʹnmõõzzid koʹdde;good.SPRL reindeer.PL.ACC leave.PST.3PL and  bad.SPRL.PL.ACC kill.PST.3PL;The best reindeer were left alive, and the weakest were killed;

Name: Can second person singular verb forms be used in generic meaning?
Are clauses with only infinitive predicates possible?
Can verbs in purposive subordinate clauses be in bare infinitive form?
Example: sij vueʹlǧǧe ǩiččâd tõn pueʹrr jânnam;3PL.NOM set.off.PST.3PL see.INF DIST.SG.ACC good land.SG.ACC;they set off to see that good land;Feist 2010: 343

Name: Are there sentences without overt verbal arguments (e.g. weather verbs)?
Example: âbrr;rain.PRS.3SG;it's raining;|kuâldd;snow.PRS.3SG;it's snowing;

Name: Is copula needed for predicate nominals in the 3rd person form of the present tense?
Example: nijdd lij äʹrǧǧ;girl.SG.NOM PRS.3SG shy.SG.NOM;the girl is shy;Feist 2010: 290

Name: Is a copula needed for predicate nominals in the past and/or future tense?
Example: Tät leäi, ašttõʹlle, reeʹǧǧes caarr;PROX.SG.NOM be.PST.3SG remember.PRS.3PL richtsar.SG.NOM;He was, they say, a rich tsar;Feist 2010: 408

Name: Can locative adverbial phrases act as predicates without a copula?
Can the same coordinating conjunction be used for NPs, VPs, and clauses?
Example: aiham da čiʹʒiham peʹjje seeʹibez kaʹlddja;bear.SG.NOM and wolf.SG.NOM put.PRS.3PL tail.PL.ACC.3PL;ice.hole.SG.ILL;bear and wolf put their tails into the hole in the ice;Feist 2010: 354|son aaʹlji vuäggad da kueʹll tääʹvti ǩidd;3SG.NOM start.PST.3SG angle.INF and fish.SG.NOM grab.PST.3SG closed;he started to angle and the fish took the bait;Feist 2010: 355

Name: Does existential negation have a separate operator?
Can standard negation be asymmetric in the present tense?
Example: Mon pooram;I eat.PRS.1SG;I eat;|mon jiõm poor;I NEG.1SG eat.CNG;I don't eat;

Name: Can non-finite dependent clauses use the standard negation construction?
Is there a special negator that combines with non-finite forms?
Are there special negative non-finite forms?
Example: taaurõš ij ni vuäittam cieʹlǩkani leeʹd;friend.SG.NOM NEG.3SG even be.able.PST.PTCP say.ABE be.INF;(my) friend was not even able to stay silent (lit. be without saying);Feist 2010: 318

Name: Is there an impersonal passive construction?
Example: Tõin	võnnsin miʹjjid uiddeeš täʹlvv-siʹjdde; that.COM boat.COM 1PL.ACC take.away.PST.3PL;winter_village.ILL;With that boat they took us away to the winter village;

Name: Are there nonfinite forms specialized on the relativization of particular core participants, e.g. subjects (S/A), direct objects (P), absolutive participants (S/P)?
Example: lookki  päʹrnn;read.PRS.PTCP boy.SG:NOM;a boy that reads;|lookkâm päʹrnn;read.PST.PTCP;a boy that has read;|lokkum ǩeʹrjj;read.PASS.PTCP book;book that has been read;

Name: Are there nonfinite forms that can relativize at least all core participants (S/A/P) and possibly also some noncore participants, e.g. locative adverbials, instruments, etc.?
Are there nonfinite forms that can relativize at least some noncore participants, e.g. locative adverbials or instruments, but cannot relativize all or some of the core participants, e.g. subjects?
Is there a specialized negative participial form, which cannot be analyzed as a specific participial marker + negation marker?
Example: Ǩeʹrjj lij looǥǥǩani; book be.PRS.3SG read.ABE.PTCP;a book that hasn't been read;
Comment: In some varieties it is possible to say e.g. puuđkani jieʹllem (end.ABE.PTCP life.SG.NOM) 'a life without an end'.

Name: Is there a future participle?
Are there participles that can encode their subject by possessive suffixes?
Can subject in at least some participial subordinate clauses be encoded in the same way as in independent clauses?
Are there participles that obligatorily agree with the nouns they modify in case and number (in all contexts)?
Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and action nominalizations?
Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and agentive nominalizations?
Example: leʹjje takai jooʹtti oummu;be.PST.3PL habitual wander.PRS.PTCP person.PL.NOM;they were habitual wandering people; Feist 2010: 213-214|jooʹtti;;habitual wanderer;

Name: Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and converbs without any additional morphological material, such as case markers?
Is OV the neutral order in affirmative imperative clauses?
Example: mõõn ton [viǯǯâd muännai ääuš];go.IMP.2SG 2SG.NOM [fetch.INF 1DU.GEN axe.SG.ACC];go, you, and fetch our axe!;Feist 2010: 329

Name: Is it possible to place an object between the negative marker and the main verb in imperative constructions?
Example: Jeäʹl leeiʹb poor!;NEG.IMP.2SG bread.SG.ACC eat.CNG;Don't eat bread (but eat something else);
Comment: Possible, but such sentences are not neutral.

Name: Are there preverbs?
Are there verbal prefixes?
Is there diminutive (hypocoristic) marking on verbs?
Can modifiers of action nominalization in agent and patient roles both be marked like possessors?
Example: Suu leeiʹb poorrmõš;3SG.GEN bread.SG.GEN eating;His eating of bread;|suu pess;3SG.GEN gun.NOM.SG;his/her gun;

Name: Can the modifier of action nominalization in patient role (e.g. "drinking of coffee") be marked like the direct object?
Do core adjectives agree with the subject noun in number in the predicative position?
Example: niõđ lie ääʹrj;girl.PL.NOM PRS.3PL shy.PL.NOM;the girls are shy;Feist 2010: 212

Name: Is it possible to form synthetic superlative?
Example: cueʹǩǩ : cueʹjjab : cueʹjjmõs;shallow : shallow-COMP : shallow-SUPL;shallow : shallower : shallowest;Feist 2010: 180

Name: Can adpositions have person/number marking?
Example: âlnnan, ââlnad, ââʹlnes;;on me, on you, on him/her;

Name: Are there separate adpositions to express goal, source, and location (without there being syncretism)?
Is case compounding possible?
Are there case categories only found in pronouns?
Does the numeral modification of a noun have an effect on its case selection?
Example: mon veʹt pukkveezz leʹjjem lååi peiʹvved;1SG.NOM EMP in.all be.PST.1SG ten.SG.NOM day.PART;altogether I was there for ten days!;Feist 2010: 249|nellj oummu mõʹnne tuõddra;four.SG.NOM men.SG.GEN go.PST.3PL fell.SG.ILL;four men went to the fell; Feist 2010: 223
Comment: Nouns modified by numerals bigger than six are in the partitive, smaller than seven are in the genitive (Feist 2010: 222-223, 249).

Name: Is the singular form of the noun also used with numerals bigger than 1?
Example: nellj oummu mõʹnne tuõddra;four.SG.NOM men.SG.GEN go.PST.3PL fell.SG.ILL;four men went to the fell;Feist 2010: 223

Name: Is there a genitive case that has an affix?
Is there a dative case used to express indirect object/receiver/goal (different from a local case)?
Is there a terminative case?
Is there a separate case to indicate without what/who an action takes place / does not take place?
Example: võõnâs ij jååʹđ ääirtää;boat.SG.NOM NEG.3SG travel.NEG oar.SG.ABE;the boat won't move without an oar;Feist 2010: 247

Name: Is there a separate case to mark the motion along or by the referent of the noun (prolative)?
Is there a locative case that marks goal?
Example: suäna mõʹnne meäcca;3DU.NOM go.PST.3PL forest.SG.ILL;the two of them went to the forest;Feist 2010: 237

Name: Is there a locative case that marks location?
Is there a locative case that marks source?
Is there case syncretism of goal and location marking?
Is there case syncretism of location and source marking?
Example: Pâʹss Treffan oummu sami liâ ceerkvest sluužvmen; Holy Trifon.SG.GEN person.PL.NOM quite be.PRS.3PL church.SG.LOC worship.PROG.PTCP;Holy Trifon's people are just in the church worshiping;Feist 2010: 239|eʹčč da jeäʹnn puõʹtte ceerkvest põrttseez;father.SG.NOM and mother.SG.NOM come.PST.3PL church.SG.LOC house.SG.ILL.3PL;father and mother came from the church to their house;Feist 2010: 240

Name: Are there two sets of local cases?
Is there a third set of local cases?
Is there a separate case for marking the means by which something is carried out (instrumental) and/or accompaniement (comitative)?
Example: son skläddneeiʹbin ǩiõʹtte čuõʹǧǧii;3SG.NOM penknife.SG.COM hand.SG.ILL prick.PST.3SG;he pricked the hand with a penknife;Feist 2010: 245

Name: Is there a separate case for marking accompaniment, which is different from the instrumental?
Is there a separate case for marking the result of change (translative) and/or a state of being (essive)?
Example: tuuʹl sääʹm leʹjje älggam ââʹnned tõn ǩieʹđj Vuâsppååʹden;formerly Skolt.Saami.PL.NOM be.PST.3PL start.PST.PTCP use.INF DIST.SG.ACC rock.SG.ACC god.ESS;formerly the Skolt Saami started to use that rock as a god;Feist 2010: 248

Name: Is there a separate case for marking the state of being (essive), which is different from the translative?
Is there a separate morphological marker for expressing equative meaning?
Is there an inflectional nominal marker for expressing benefactive or destinative semantics independent from the dative?
Is there in addition to the basic declension a declension different from a possessive declension?
Is it possible to use singular with paired body parts/clothing/accessories that accompany them?
Can the marking of the possessor in the attributive construction vary?
Example: muu eʹčč;I.GEN father;my father;|muʹst eʹčč;I.LOC father;my father;

Name: Can the possessor in the attributive construction be marked with the nominative?
Is non-singular possession marked in the possessive declension?
Example: muõrram : muõrran;tree.SG.NOM.1SG : tree.PL.NOM.1SG;my tree : my trees;Feist 2010: 175

Name: Can 2Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Can 3Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Is there animacy distinction in independent interrogative pronouns?
Example: mii vs. kii;;what vs. who;Feist 2010: 325

Name: When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for animates other than humans?
When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for inanimates?
Can a demonstrative stem be used in the function of a pronoun with 3rd person singular human referent?
Example: Tõt lij hääʹsǩes ooumaž;that be.PRS.3SG funny.ATTR person.SG.NOM;s/he is a funny person;

Name: Is the order of possessive suffix and case suffix across the paradigm the same?
Comment: In the comitative and abessive cases the case suffix follows the possessive suffix, whereas in  other cases it precedes the possessive suffix. However, the case and possessive suffix cannot always be separated.

Name: Is the order of number and case suffixes fixed across the paradigm the same?
Example: siõʹzzid;aunt.PL.ACC;;Feist 2010: 229

Name: Are there different words for mother’s brother and father’s brother?
Example: jieʹǩǩ;;fathers older brother;|čieʹcc;;fathers younger brother;|jeän;;mothers brother;

Name: Are there different words for younger and older relative for other relations than siblings?
Example: kuäʹsǩǩ;;mothers older sister;|mueʹđđ;;mothers younger sister;|jieʹǩǩ;;fathers older brother;| čieʹcc;;fathers younger brother;

Name: Is there animacy distinction for both concepts 'new/young' and 'old'?
Is there distinction for both 'warm' and 'cold' based on whether referring to weather or to temperature of objects?
Is there contrastive length of consonants?
Example: paarr [paːrːᵃ] couple.NOM.SG vs. paar [paːrᵃ] couple.GEN.SG

Name: Is there contrastive length of vowels?
Example: võrr [vɘrːːᵃ] blood.SG.NOM vs. võõr [vɘːrᵃ] blood.SG.GEN

Name: Is there contrast between short and long unstressed vowels?
Is there contrast in duration of geminate consonants?
Example: mädd [mædːːᵃ] soil.SG.NOM vs. määdd [mæːdːᵃ] soil.SG.GEN

Name: Are there more than two phonological quantities?
Example: mõʹnne [mɘːnʲːe] go.PRT.3PL, mõõnnâd [mɘːnːᴈd] go.INF, mõõnam [mɘːnam] go.PRS.1SG

Name: Are there extralong syllables?
Example: äälǥam [æːl.ɣam] begin.PRS.1SG

Name: Is the main foot structure trochaic?
Example: võõnâs [ˈvɘː.nᴈs] 'boat', maaiʹlmest [ˈmɑːjlʲ.mest] world.SG.LOC

Name: Is there lexically distinctive word stress?
Is there morphologically conditioned stress?
Example: âʹnškueʹtted [ᴈnʲ.ʃkuetʲːed] 'begin to use'
Comment: ue' is stressed

Name: Is there fixed primary stress?
Example: aʹrvveed [ˈarʲvv.ˌeːd] ʹguessʹ

Name: Is there stress in heavy syllables?
Is there non-initial primary stress?
Is there palatal vowel harmony?
Comment: There is some kind of vowel harmony mutta this does not depend on the frontness/backness of vowels.

Name: Is there velar vowel harmony?
Comment: There is no ɤ or ɯ in Skolt Saami.

Name: Is there labial vowel harmony?
Are there rising diphthongs?
Comment: All diphtongs are lowering.

Name: Are there lowering diphthongs?
Example: ceäʹlǩǩed [t͡sĕælʲcːed] 'say'
Comment: All diphtongs are lowering: iɘ ‹iõ› ‹iõʹ›, uɘ ‹uõ› ‹uõʹ›, eæ ‹eä› ‹eäʹ›, uæ ‹uä› ‹uäʹ›, eᴈ ‹eâ› ‹eäʹ›, uᴈ ‹uâ› ‹uẹʹ›, ie ‹ieʹ›, ue ‹ueʹ›, (iε ‹iẹʹ›), (uε ‹uẹʹ›), iᴈ ‹iâ›, uɔ ‹uå›

Name: Is there qualitative contrast between subsets of short and long vowels?
Are there full vs. reduced vowels as contrastive subsets?
Is there front high rounded vowel ü [y]?
Comment: [y] exists only in new loanwords such as fysikk 'physics'.

Name: Is there front midhigh rounded vowel ö [ø]?
Is there back high unrounded vowel ï [ɯ]?
Is there back midhigh unrounded vowel ë [ɤ]?
Is there back low round vowel [ɒ]?
Comment: The phoneme marked <å> in standard ortography can be realised as [ɒ] in some varieties, but more commonly as [ɔ] or [oa].

Name: Is there contrast between low and mid front vowels (ä [æ] vs. e [e])?
Example: ekka [ekːa] 'at night' vs. äkka [ækːa] old woman.SG.ILL

Name: Are there word-initial consonant clusters?
Example: kruugg [kruːgːᵃ] 'circle'
Comment: Also ståkkan 'glass', prääʹzniǩ 'celebration' etc.

Name: Are there word-internal consonant clusters in syllable onset?
Example: mainsted [mainᵃsted] 'speak'

Name: Are there consonant clusters in syllable coda?
Example: maaiʹlmest [ˈmɑːjlʲ.mest] world.SG.LOC

Name: Are there clusters of three or more consonants in a word between vowels?
Example: veerstast [veːrstast] verst.SG.LOC

Name: Are there word-final clusters of three or more consonants?
Comment: In word forms such as verstt [verstːᵃ] the consonant cluster is not phonologically word-final, because it is followed by a reduced (overshort) vowel.

Name: Are there palatalized dentals?
Example: mââʹnn [mᴈːnʲːᵉ] egg vs. mâânn [mᴈːnːᵃ] go.PRS.3SG
Comment: Skolt Saami has suprasegmental palatalization, so the difference between mââʹnn [mᴈːnʲːᵉ] 'egg' and mâânn [mᴈːnːᵃ] go.PRS.3SG is strictly speaking not only that of [n] vs. [nʲ].

Name: Are there palatalized labials and velars?
Comment: Suprasegmental palatalization apparently does not affect labials, and velars become wholly palatal by its effect (e.g. k > ǩ (c)-.

Name: Is there palatal stop [c]?
Example: ǩiõll [ciɘllᵃ] 'language'

Name: Is there palatal nasal [ɲ]?
Example: njargg [ɲargːᵃ] 'cape'

Name: Is there palatal lateral [ʎ]?
Example: villj [viʎːːᵃ] 'brother'

Name: Is there phonemic velar nasal [ŋ]?
Example: šõŋŋ [ʃɘŋːːᵃ] 'weather'

Name: Is there dental affricate [t͡s]?
Example: ceäʹlǩǩed [t͡sĕælʲcːed] 'say'

Name: Is there non-alveolar affricate (e.g. [t͡ʃ], [͡cɕ])?
Example: čääʹcc [t͡ʃæːcːᵉ] 'water'

Name: Is there a phonological contrast between [s] and postalveolar sibilant [ʃ]?
Example: suõnn [suɘnːᵃ] 'blood vessel' vs. šuõnn [ʃuɘnːᵃ] 'sunbeam', strääšš [stræːʃː] 'horror'

Name: Are there voiced plosives [b, g, d]?
Example: kõõddâs [kɘːdːᴈs] 'threshold'
Comment: Also aabbâs 'ABC-book', kruuggâst circle.SG.LOC, bliin 'pancake', domm 'house', boʹhtter 'hero'.

Name: Is there glottal stop [ˀ]?
Is there phonological contrast between plain and labial velar consonants (e.g. [k] vs. [kʷ])?
Is there a constraint on word-initial r?
Is there laryngeal fricative [h]?
Example: hä'lbb [hælʲbːᵉ]
Comment: However, word-initial h may also be pronounced [x].

Name: Is there voiced velar fricative [ɣ]?
Example: jooǥǥâst [joːɣːᴈst] river.SG.LOC

Name: Is there voiceless velar fricative [x]?
Example: uhss [uxsːᵃ] 'door', ähšš [æxʃ'ːᵃ] 'axe'
Comment: This sound reminds the respective sound in Russian and it differs from the Finnish [h].

Name: Is there voiced dental fricative [ð]?
Example: teâđam [teᴈðam] know.PRS.1SG

Name: Is there phonemic labio-velar approximant [w]?
Example: põõllâd [pɘːwːᴈd] 'to fear'
Comment: The "l-vocalization" in non-palatal environments is a relatively recent phenomenon and does not occur in all dialects, but it is favored in modern standard language.

Name: Is there voiceless labiodental fricative [f]?
Example: fiinâs [fiːnᴈs] 'fine, tidy'

Name: Is there radical qualitative consonant gradation?
Example: tie'tted [tietːed] 'know' vs. teâđam [teᴈðam] know.PRS.1SG

Name: Is there quantitative consonant gradation?
Example: muõrr [muɘrːᵃ] wood.SG.NOM vs. muõr [muɘrᵃ] wood.SG.GEN
